@ohgoditsranor @clippedgcds also while they have a long way to go, we praise FF for keeping old content "relevant" (tho there is no reason to do it once you've seen it), and this is the first sign of them ever even making an effort. not perfect, but an improvement.

@alethya_ like i test professionally and unless i had pre-knowledge, an element inspector, or QA tools that pointed it out, i wouldn't bother banging on a wall that long--especially in a game so wide in scope. no time for that shit.

@alethya_ yeah i mean that's the thing, if all doors were x number of hits to open, then yeah, eventually you'd figure that out based on the look alone. but the fact that it is so *egregiously* many more hits than normal means all but the most deranged people would move on after a few.
@alethya_ I mean, hidden stuff *is* great, don't get me wrong, but 30+ hits to open a fake wall borders on either data mining or automation needed to find it.

That's not to say hidden stuff like this is inherently bad design, quite the opposite, but 30 hits is so egregious that either a) there's a hint in game people have missed (and it's still a needless amount of hits), b) it's a bug, or c) someone is trolling.
Alternatively, it's the developers figuring out what kind of deranged shit they can get away with and still have people go 'well ackshually, this is good!'
I love the people in the replies twisting themselves in knots to call this great game design when it's probably just a bug. https://t.co/9bFdLzNhUt

@Wonton_ @Zolmation @MISKAESL a lot of my keybinding habits come from tanking, and more specifically, really starting to get into heroic and mythic raiding on a couple of bosses that emphasized very precise and controlled tank positioning and movement (nefarion and conclave, in particular).

@Wonton_ @Zolmation @MISKAESL in FF i also tend to put my weave abilities on 7 to 9 (or higher) and then have a keyboard-mouse-mouse-keyboard rhythm. 

only downside is i have to make some changes when i don't have an MMO mouse.

@Wonton_ @Zolmation @MISKAESL it also opens up 7 to = and all their modifiers as comfortable binds. my defensive cooldowns are usually on shift+0/-/= for example, which is the bottom row of my mouse keys, so very quick.

@Wonton_ @Zolmation @MISKAESL i actually use an MMO mouse, but i mirror 1 to = on it and swap between the keyboard and mouse dynamically depending on what i'm doing. using keyboard is easier on my hands at rest, but if i'm moving for example i can keep my main abilities running without any weird contortions.
@MISKAESL @Zolmation yours are a horror show

@Zolmation @MISKAESL putting your fingers on 1-2-3 is reducing how many buttons your fingers can reach. can easily reach ` from 2 with no stretching, and 6 from 4 without stretching. if i'm on 1-2-3, i can reach `-5 without stretching, not to mention it opens up R, T, F, G, etc more easily.
@Zolmation all my "1-2-3" combos are on 4-3-2.

i've had a bunch of people recommend slay the spire to me. i will probably never play it, because i actively dislike deck builders and card battlers, and i'm not a huge fan of roguelikes in general either. the game should not, however, in any way change to accommodate my tastes.

as an example: all the things people love about soulsborne games do *absolutely nothing* for me. i could not be less interested if i actively tried. same with card-based battle systems of pretty much any kind. but i would never call those genre's *bad*--they're just not for me.

that's not to say that those people's opinions are invalid, but more that i think trying to make a game that appeals to everyone is walking the road to mediocrity, and if you don't like something it's fine to just say "not for me" rather than "bad".

and that's not for everyone, which is fine, but it always comes off a little bit like complaining about something that a bunch of people--especially long time fans--think is *the best part* which drives me up the wall.

yeah, it slows open world gameplay. no, i don't think it's a major issue--killing mobs in the open world is not particularly fun in any mmo. the dialogue and cutscenes are not just there to slow you down, almost every line serves a purpose to the characters and world building.

if there is one criticism of ffxiv that i both understand and absolutely despise hearing, it's about the pacing and density of dialogue and cutscenes.

i completely understand where people are coming from with it, but at the same time feel like they're playing a different game.

@Rogue5Druid3 Basically you hardcast one of your long casts to open, then use the dual cast on the opposite and use your first weave window to stack two instant cast buffs. Next two GCDs you dump all into one side. Guarantees you can predict your opening finisher balance.
@Rogue5Druid3 But also I completely understand how a ything less than 'this is how you should be doing it' can feel like shit, especially when you're not really comfortable with a class.

@Rogue5Druid3 It's a big last resort for mechanics considerations since if you're in that position, you could also just dump into one side to swap your balance, but yeah, its a lot better than nothing.

@Rogue5Druid3 As for breaking the alternating cast muscle memory, practicing the standard opener (Verthunder-Veraero-(Accel-Swift)-Thunder-(Potion)-Thunder-(Embolden-Manafication)-Melee Combo) helps with it a bit.
@Rogue5Druid3 You can also just finish on the higher mana finisher if you absolutely need to. Chance for a proc on the higher Mana is better than a guaranteed override.

@Rogue5Druid3 It can be really easy to get into an alternating cast pattern, but you can just dump 4-6 casts into one side without being in too much danger of unbalancing depending on your start point. You need to unbalance by 30+ before it becomes an issue.

@Rogue5Druid3 You sometimes have to override to finish when you need to for mechanics (or just have really good procs and can't keep pooling), but sometimes if you have say (random numbers) 55B/62W with a Fire proc and no Stone proc, you just avoid Verthunder until you flip your balance.
@Vetaro There's also some license stuff, but not in the sense that zombie is trademarked. If you work on a Walking Dead property, for example, you're just not allowed to use the word.

@Vetaro It's more a genre blindness thing. If you call your monsters zombies, it comes with the expectation that a) your characters know basic things about zombies, to call them zombies, and b) on a meta level that your not-zombies have to follow certain conventions.

@MagdalenaDK An important part of this is that you're not a supporting character to a cast of main characters. You are the main character of the story, and some of your friends and companions are also main characters, but ultimately the game is the story of your character. And the story

@MagdalenaDK It's also very much not 'you're just another adventurer in the world'. It starts like that, but very quickly puts that aside (we're talking like mid 30s level wise) and does (well) what WoW has intermittently tried and failed to do, which is make your character the hero.

@Rogue5Druid3 @ohgoditsranor the augmented 520 stuff came in 5.5, whereas the 510 stuff was in 5.4. it's pretty much just a gear catchup mechanic, especially since you can get it faster than the base revelation gear.
@Rogue5Druid3 @ohgoditsranor the 520 upgraded crafted pieces can't be pentamelded (that's the Advanced Melding Forbidden line on them), only the 510 stuff.

@Rogue5Druid3 @ohgoditsranor ofc your BiS sets, because of stat tiering, are also designed with what food you're using in mind too, just to complicate things. it can be pretty fun to fuck around with when you're in the middle of gearing, tho admittedly i'm glad not to be designing the BiS lists.

@Rogue5Druid3 @ohgoditsranor so if your options are all SkS/SpS pieces in that situation, then it becomes a bit of a game of "is there a comfortable GCD tier you can reach, and if not, do the secondary gains from dropping ilvl to drop SkS/SpS make up the difference."

@Rogue5Druid3 @ohgoditsranor yeah that kind of ilvl gap is *usually* enough to make it universally better, though there have been exceptions (especially with unique rings). BLM also has the advantage of actually using all their secondary stats--BiS for DNC for example, is to have absolutely no SkS from gear.

@Rogue5Druid3 @ohgoditsranor (this is also why you'll sometimes see a BiS list that uses an item that is strictly worse on paper than another option--it's letting you hit thresholds more cleanly, which allows you to move a meld, etc, and end up with more overall useful stats.)

@Rogue5Druid3 @ohgoditsranor to finely tune your stats, in some cases sitting on the exact thresholds for each.

and, of course, damage tuning for week one prog can very easily get into "you literally don't have enough vitality for this" territory, though i think it's been a while since it was that tight.

@Rogue5Druid3 @ohgoditsranor there's quite a bit of nuance to it. since every secondary stat is tiered, it's very easy to be in a situation where you have, say, 23 DET that isn't actually doing anything until you add ~2 more. one of the major advantages of a later stage relic weapon is being able to use it

@alethya_ Effectively one guild tried to become two and the drama of it left no guild at all. I was recruiting at the time and pulled a ton of people from those situations.

@alethya_ As an example, if you're a GM cutting your roster down by half or more, and someone is fairly sure they're not making your shortlist, they're 100% gonna try to poach friends, etc. This happened a lot in MoP with guilds moving from 25 to 10. Watched multiple guilds die to it.

@alethya_ Think this is a little bit just us being more familiar with our current situation. I 100% believe that it would save some guilds, but I'm equally confident it outright kills a bunch that can't handle the wind down and/or split in a healthy manner. There's a ton of room for drama.

@alethya_ It's tough for me to draw many conclusions on this one. My guild is able to recruit fine on not-Draenor rn (tons of apps actually), but there is a decent chance that it's because guilds are folding.

@alethya_ (also unironically there are a ton of players who would not be able to cut mythic raiding with the increased personal responsibility that inherently comes with a smaller raid size, even if they can scrape by in 20 man)

@alethya_ Not to say it should be completely off the table, I just think this is an area where you do stuff like lockout changes, cross faction, cross server, etc to increase accessibility first before you even look at 10 man.

@alethya_ Raiders. Taking a 20 man roster that has played together for a long time and telling them they have to drop 10+ players is a big ask for your, frankly, most loyal subscribers, and that's before you even get into the other issues with smaller raid sizes.

@alethya_ Lockouts for sure need to change, no question there. And I would never suggest even 15 for a newer MMO. It's more that they don't have the trust with their players to be making sweeping changes, and while you might make things more accessible, you also alienate a lot of current

@alethya_ Given the connection people have to their specs, etc, I don't think you do anything with that except further damage your relationship with long time players, and frankly wow is not drowning in new players to replace them at this point in its life cycle.
@alethya_ 15 man is more feasible, still shares the issues, but on a smaller scale.

@alethya_ Balance problem. You have to fundamentally rethink class design in WoW, which is probably more harm than help given the community's aversion to sweeping changes (scars from constant class changes) and homogenization.

@alethya_ 10 man is undoubtably easier to manage and the roster boss is the worst part of mythic, but I think the ship is long past sailed on 10 man in WoW from a core design level. The number of specs alone were a problem for 10 man back in Wrath/Cata let alone now, and it's not just a

@Talarianjs One of the most frustrating things I've ever done is Savage content with a big skill disparity in the group. I think it's likely okay if one player is just faster/better than the group, but one or two players well below group average is *infuriating* in a way it isn't in WoW.

@Talarianjs Doing casual Savage clears asked a lot more from me than raiding at world 700-1000 has in Shadowlands, but both are a decent step below tanking/making calls at world 100 with way less gear. As, I suspect, would be savage without weekly gear increases.

@Talarianjs That said, I think the content isn't super comparable for the most part beyond an 'it takes this much time and effort to clear' level. The focuses are different. And personally I think the responsibility and cognitive load in FF content is higher than WoW for the average player.

@Talarianjs The important distinction with the high end content in FF tho is that it's a lot tougher to carry a mediocre player through the content than it is in WoW. Not impossible, mind, but, well, I sold enough WoW clears to know how easy it is there.

@Talarianjs From what I've seen (cleared a couple savage tiers when current, casually pulled older ultimates when current), ultimate is, in the same expansion, roughly equivalent to an end mythic boss--but without gear nerfs. Savage ranges from first-three to second last mythic boss level.
flip side of this is that in WoW you're significantly more likely to luck into a genuinely *good* player, but unless they're good enough to carry the group, it doesn't matter.

i cannot stress enough how important this is for FF14 btw. it's much easier to tweak what you think the opener is from playing the game, to what a guide says, than it is to internalize it all at once.

it is also a lot easier to adjust your opener when you understand it, then

there are very few MMO classes i've played where some game experience isn't enough to carve out a rough approximation of the rotation just from playing. if you do that, you'll have an easier time picking up the optimizations.

pressing buttons without having an understanding of why, but because a guide told you to in that order, makes you less understanding of your class, and less adaptable.

it also straight up takes more time to internalize an opener if you don't know your abilities already.
hot take: people would be better at classes if they stopped making step 1 be "read a class guide". this is true in WoW and *especially* in FF14.

I get why people who swear by legacy get upset about that, even though it's a waste of your energy. But a ton of those people just turn around and do the same thing back, for the same reason: they're used to legacy, and they suck at using standard properly.

It's common for WoW players to come into the game having used standard movement for the better part of two decades and call Legacy shit. They do this because they're used to standard and legacy *does* feel like shit when you're very used to standard and have never used legacy.
In my experience, anyone who tells you one or the other can't do x thing is full of shit and just doesn't know how to use it properly. That applies to both control schemes.
Each has their strengths and weaknesses. The weaknesses for each can be worked around, but may require some jank. Whichever one you personally can use most intuitively is what you should use.
People who insist either legacy or standard movement are strictly better across the board are definitely one of my biggest annoyances in the wider FF community.

@KihraOfTemerity yeah, i mean i've done work testing specifically autoscaling on AWS for games, i've seen the kind of dumb shit that happens.

@ohgoditsranor as kihra pointed out, it is *entirely* possible that it's a problem with their load balancing or scaling code solutions. because testing at scale is hard, and testing to simulate active users in the scale measure at 7 digits is near impossible.

doesn't make it not kinda funny.

@KihraOfTemerity yeah, i mean bugs happen, and if that's all it was then that is a completely different thing, i just find it really funny that people bash other MMOs for not having (or not appearing to have) AWS autoscaling and then the same shit happens to literally amazon.

so, for most companies, "why aren't the servers just on AWS or GCP" is a question that sounds smart, but isn't as smart as people think.

but when you're *literally amazon* yeah, how the fuck are the servers not on AMAZON WEB SERVICES to handle this load.

calibrate, and you have to do it in the months after to decommision those servers as well. and that's not even mentioning all the game-side challenges that come with something like AWS integration that are side-steppable by running your own hardware.

accessing dozens or hundreds of databases, you're not on cloud servers the same way your uncle's business website is, you're just renting servers. and you don't *only* get to do that for the time when your users peak, you have to do it in the months beforehand to test and

autoscaling at the, well, scale, that most of the really big launches are talking about it *prohibitively* expensive for most teams. game server hardware needs to be properly calibrated (see FFXIV's E4S enrage bug for why), and when you're talking hundreds of thousands of users

Ironically, despite what dipshit gamers think every time a new game is released, New World is the first MMO release where they really don't have an excuse to have autoscaling cloud server infrastructure.

@Rogue5Druid3 To add to this, I think this is one of those tool tips that got bloated by iteration. Iirc you used to be punished decently harshly for not having started your next song before the old one expired, which you obviously wanted to do at the last possible second to avoid drift
@Rogue5Druid3 It's a bit different in a full AoE situation (though Mages resets also resets your AoE oGCD ability), but for cleave situations (especially spread cleave) I think it's a ST increase.

@Rogue5Druid3 It does a little bit, at like 2-3 target, since you only spend one GCD to *refresh* your DoTs on a target and the main benefit of the extra DoTs are faster refreshes on your oGCD abilities.

@Rogue5Druid3 interestingly, this is one of the only classes that scales with number of targets beyond simply being able to multidot. since the buffs from each song come from your DoT ticks, having more out means more buffs, particularly in Wanderer's and Mage's.
@Rogue5Druid3 yep, lets Army's Paeon (the most boring of the songs, gameplay wise) contribute to your Wanderer's Minuet burst window
